monogr.title: Woodalls viaticum: the path-way to the surgions chest : Containing chirurgicall instrvctions for the yonger sort of surgions now imployed in the service of His Maiestie for the intended reliefe of Rochell. And composed by Iohn Woodall, one of the present masters or governor of the companie of Barber surgions London. Intended chiefly for the better curing of wounds made by gun-shott. Published by authoritie
monogr.author: Woodall, John

div.head: ¶ THE PREFACE.
div.p:
LOving Brethren, for as much as these times doe rather menace VVarre then Peace, men of our calling should be readie ad omne quare, for our King and Country. Wee and our Country haue beene long happy in peace, and now it seemes the times presage the contrary. Wherefore from the wise heathen Philosopher, let vs all learne as followeth, Iam tua res agitur pare cum proximus ardet. I desire in briefe, to let you know, that our Company were commanded by Authoritie, to provide sixteene of the best Surgions at this time to be had for his Majesties speciall service, such as are men most expert in the healing of wounds made with Gun-shott. And generally, for the most part, I know many of vs that would be esteemed good Surgions, being put to it, at the
first will be somewhat to seeke therein, how much more then our young men. Wherefore the matter of providing, preparing, and fitting his Majesties service, being by his Highnes referred to our Corporation. And our Company having for the time deputed my selfe to the worke. I am tyed in conscience to doe somewhat, though I confesse, it be little to the better inabling and incouraging our younger men vnto their duties in that point. But before my entrance thereunto, I could in my dutie doe no lesse then to acquaint you with those especiall favours which it hath pleased our gracious King to bestow vpon our Corporation in particular, aboue and beyond his ever-blessed Ancestors, for our incouragement, to enable vs the more chearefully to serue him First, his Highnes hath beene pleased to augment the monethly wages of each Surgion and Surgions-mate in his Sea-service, almost to a third penny. He hath also beene graciously pleased to giue as free a benevolence to the Surgions in all his Sea-services, which never was given them before, as followeth, viz. to all Surgions that serue in his Highnes owne Ships, I meane towards
the furnishing of the Surgions Chests, for each of them xl. Vnto each Marchants Ship, imployed in his service vl. And to each New-castle Ship iijl. And neverthelesse, his Highnes is well pleased that the Surgions may demand and take by the head of all men that are in pay in any of his Shipps ijd. of each man by the moneth, as they did before. And for the Surgions in his Land-service at present, he alloweth each Surgeon ijs. vjd. the day, which is iijl. xvs. the moneth, and to each mate iijl. a moneth: And moreover, provideth, and giveth to each Surgion appointed to 250. men a Surgeons Chest of xvijl. vallew, and over and aboue a Magazin or store-chest of xlviijl. vallew, for to supply and furnish vpon all wants. His Highnes hath further beene well pleased to giue authoritie vnto the Masters and Governors of our Societie, for to haue the making, compounding, fitting, and ordering of all the Medicines, as well Physicals Chirurgicall; together with all other provisions belonging to the Surgions Chest, he hath referred to the Masters and Governors of our Societie. These favours and priviledges our Corporation haue received from
his Highnes, together with his gracious favour and graunt vnto vs of a new Charter, wherein he hath likewise gratiously beene pleased to promise to confirme all our priviledges formerly graunted vnto vs, and to giue vs divers new priviledges for the better subsistance of our Corporation in future times.

And now having acquainted you with his Maiesties favours vnto our Corporation, it followeth in my dutie that I should acquaint the younger sort of Surgions with the vse of the Surgions Chest, I meane the particular medicines therein contained, and that in some methodicall manner, were it not that time hastens me to an end before I begin, yet neverthelesse I haue strained of time to lend the younger sort a word or two for a Viaticum, not to all as a teacher, but as a loving Remembrancer to the elder, which I pray you to peruse, and vse as you haue occasion. And so in Gods name without painting of phrases, or collecting of great Authors, my methode you may know by the plainenesse of the stile, and my methode is no other then the old beaten path-way of all Surgions, wherin each Artist ought to be vnderstanding: And if any Artist
by forgetfulnesse erre, I desire but to informe his memory, and craue his charitable acceptance. And for the younger sort, I know it is charitie to shew them, for they haue neede, and ought to desire and seeke knowledge, according to an old doctrine of that sweet Lillie in his Grammer rules, viz.

l.hi: Qui dubitat, qui sepe rogat mea dicta tenebit.
Is qui nil dubitat, nil capit inde boni.

div.p: I knowing you could not haue the learned advise of the graue Doctors at hand to advise you, made me presume I confesse somewhat beyond my scope: Wherefore in want of the aforesaid helpes, consult with good Authors in their wants, with the Surgions mate, and this poore Extempore.
